titleStmt.title: Despatch from Beverly Y. Payne to A. A. Adee, November 27, 1887

bibl.title: Despatch from Beverly Y. Payne to A. A. Adee, November 27, 1887
Despatches from United States Consuls in Monrovia, 1852-1906

correspAction.roleName: U.S. Second Assistant Secretary of State

p.add: Mr. Payne sh. write on seals at ch paper in spite of his grief

div1.p: Sir, It becomes my painful duty to acknowledge the receipt of your communication of the 24th at time announcing the death of Honerable Elihu B. Washburne, who was at one time Secretary of State of the United States, with inetruchin to adopt the usual symbol of public mourning for a period of ten days as a testimony of respect to the memory of the deceased; which was immediately obeyed. I conveyed to the Government of Liberia through the State Department the o a d instelliganer; and I am advised by the Secretary of State, to convey to gear, the sympathy of the Government of
of Liberia in the taking off of such an eminent Statesman; and with the Government of the United States in the loss it has sustained in the death of so prominent and honored citizen.
I have th honor to be Sir, Your obedient Servant Beverly Y. Payne U.S. Acting Vice Consul
